results.title: Pitch Black Heist
results.creator_credit: John Maclean, Gerardine O'Flynn, Film4, UK Film Council and DMC Film
results.brief_description: Liam (Liam Cunningham) and Michael (Michael Fassbender) are professional safe crackers who meet on a simple job to relieve an office safe from its contents. The catch is a light-activated alarm system.

results.title: The Race
results.creator_credit: Nikki Rose, Kinetoscope Productions and First Light
results.brief_description: Neil and David met at nursery school. There was something different about Neil but David liked him, even though he often got himself into a bad temper. Neil knew that because of his condition eventually they would part company but David vowed that they would always remain best friends.

results.title: Prehistoric Pet Shop
results.creator_credit: Chris Barnard, Mathew Buck, George Ing, Create Studios, Dacoit Studios, Evil Twin Artworks and First Light
results.brief_description: Prehistoric Pet Shop is about a caveman whose alarm clock stops working. But not just any alarm clock - the clock was a bird with an unfortunate heart problem. The caveman goes to the pet shop to complain about his faulty alarm clock. A homage to Monty Python’s parrot sketch, this hilarious short reveals that complaining can get you more than just a new alarm clock.

results.title: Pirates of the Indian Ocean
results.creator_credit: Omni Rahman, Enamul Khan, Rafi Rahman, Northamptonshire Bangladeshi Association, Wind & Foster Media and First Light
results.brief_description: Clumsy but lovable DJ duo Mankind and Small-Steps have built a devoted following to their pirate radio show. Raging against the machine in their own inimitable style, will they reach the top of radio programming or be caught on the wrong side of the law before they reach their dream?

results.title: Proud 2 Be Me!
results.creator_credit: Isabelle Tonna, Amy Rowe, Jessica Smith, Charlotte Kinsella, Chloe McKenna, Leah Felsbourg and Hannah Petrowski
results.brief_description:
A story of a little, white monster who feels like he doesn’t belong. He tries to make himself fit in, which doesn’t quite work out. The other little monsters finally decide that they like the little white monster just the way he is.

Under the category ‘Bullying. No Way! - Primary’, Years 5 and 6, St Luke’s Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Return
results.brief_description: Static images of an old country house are combined with voices of the past to evocative effect. Haunting and nostalgic, ‘Return’ conveys the life that exists in old, abandoned places.

results.title: The Respect Quest [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Christopher Halse, Liam Blake and Tea Tree Gully Primary School
results.brief_description:
Time Monsters are spreading disrespect in the community and causing havoc. Help local villagers and elders restore respect by defeating the Time Monsters with a magic boomerang. Jump on platforms, collect coins and explore through the mountains of time. Money gained on the quest will help rebuild the villages after respect is restored.

This trailer illustrates how the game is played.
Under the category ‘Primary Games’, Tea Tree Gully Primary School’s Liam Blake and Christopher Halse, Grade 5, were the Screen It 2011 winners.

results.title: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton
results.brief_description: The 1960s brought on a change in government in Australia, resulting in greater funding towards the arts and Australia’s film industry in particular. In turn, this political change gave rise to what was to be called the ‘Australian New Wave’ in cinema. Celebrated film critic, David Stratton, shares his recollections of this pivotal time with fellow key players: Jan Chapman, Matt Carroll, Paul Cox and Phillip Noyce (via SKYPE). This panel discussion was filmed at ACMI as part of the ‘Margaret and David: 25 years talking movies’ exhibition.
results.title_for_label: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton

results.title: Reminiscing
results.creator_credit: Alf Thornton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alf Thornton fondly recalls his time serving in the Australian Navy during World War II, when letting your mates down was more feared than being killed. When Thornton returned, he spent most of his time trying to regain his lost youth but eventually found an anchor on the H.M.A.S. Castlemaine.

results.title: Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences interviews
results.creator_credit: Jason White, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences’ is the first in the ‘New Horizons’ series of ACMI commissions. Gladwell uses filmic devices such as slow-motion and long pans to capture both tightly choreographed and improvised performances by breakdancers, skateboarders and BMX bike riders in a combination of rural and city settings. The resulting works, which he describes as “performative landscapes” are both rhythmic and poetic - distorting speed, gravity, space and time; exploring visual and spatial paradoxes. He discusses his art practice and his collaboration with other performers and artists for this exhibition. Other interviews include; Sarah Tutton (ACMI curator), Josh Raymond (Gladwell producer) Vivienne Wong (Australian Ballet) and Lamaroc (street dancer).
